'The main point dealt with in discussion was whether it waspremature to make a declaration in the sense proposed at this, juncture. It wais stated that this course would probably befavoured by several of the Allied Governments, who were interestednot so much in what would happen to a limited number of outstanding enemy leaders (in whose case public trial was unlikely to be a suitable procedure*), but rather in regard to crimesri committed by enemy nationals other than the outstanding leaders;for example, German officers who were known to have taken a prominent part in maltreating Allied nationals in concentrationcamps.The "War, Cabinet were also reminded that Lord Vansittart hadthe following Motion for discussion in the House of Lords : "To ask His Majesty's Government, whether they havetaken, or intend to take, any steps to ensure that no German. criminal shall find asylum in any neutral country; and to movefor Papers." ..'* On the other hand, it was urged that there was no immediateneed for action on the lines proposed, and that action in this matter would be more effective if it was taken nearer the time when theenemy's resistance was finally breaking.The War Cabinefs decisions were as follows :-(1) The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs was asked tobring his Paper again before the War Cabinet in threemonths' time. (43) 264) informing them of recent developments with regard to the detention and deportation-tion of Mr. Maybank, late General Secretary of the Northern Rhodesian Mine-Workers' Union. The General Council of theTrades Union, Congress had asked the Secretary of State to reopen the case on the grounds that the Governor had acted in a high-handed manner and that Mr. Maybank had been deported becauseof his Trade Union activities. Both these suggestions wereunfounded and there could be no question of altering the decision which had been taken. The Secretary of State therefore proposedthat Sir Walter Citrine should be informed that the Governor ofNorthern Rhodesia had acted with the full support of His Majesty'sGovernment and that, in the absence of any new facts, there was no ground for. reconsidering the decision taken.The War Cabinet-Agreed to the course proposed.Funeral of 4.
